Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Non-Conservative Approach for Signal Amplification

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit of the proposed activity:
Signal amplification remains a major engineering challenge in the field of bioelectronics and microelectronics. With the wide spread use of mobile devices it is universally realized that amplifier performance remains inhibited in many circumstances in which the incoming signal strength is weak making performance unacceptable. A number of engineering solutions have been offered and each of them has their own limitations. The objective of this proposal is to explore a novel approach for fabrication and device evaluation of a signal amplifier operable at acoustic frequencies (20 Hz - 20 kHz) such as in human hearing-aid devices. The PIs propose to adopt a non-conservative approach to attain the objective by using the integrated structures consisting of films of non-classical semiconductor materials (such as modified iron-titanate) on buffered silicon substrates. Studies of their current-voltage characteristics under the influence of an external electric field provided by a gate oxide will lead to the development of reliable and novel microelectronic signal boosters. The approach described herein offers a novel and completely non-conservative approach for fabricating and evaluating a signal amplifier having many applications including in bio-electronics. The proposed solution, methodology, and materials selection pose challenges that could culminate in fulfillment of intellectual curiosity and technical success. Should this approach become successful it will be a paradigm-shifting contribution to the very nature of microelectronic technology.

Broader Impact of the proposed activity:
This research will have broader impact on the education of engineering students, directly impact the field of microelectronics and radiation-hard electronics and might open a new product line for dual-use electronics market. The PIs will make special efforts to recruit female and Hispanic students, both graduate and undergraduate, in this research and thereby will open to them an opportunity for life-long learning in a highly technical field. In support of training the students for the research outlined here, the PIs will offer a special topic course on Electroceramics in Fall Semester 2010. Wide dissemination of the obtained results by publishing and presenting lectures at national and international conferences will be another example of its broader impact. A multiyear research program is envisioned at this stage if this exploratory research proves encouraging.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soon after William Shockley, John Bardeen and Walter Brittain demonstrated the first solid state transistor device on a single crystal germanium substrate in December, 1947 in Bell Labs the name “transistor” was selected out of six different choices. Transistor is the contraction of “transconductance varistor” which was one of the six names proposed. Over the years, in the meantime, it has been forgotten that transistor is historically associated with varistor.

In this research we have established conclusively for the first time the coexistence of a varistor and a transistor as a hybrid device capable of performing operations typically associated with each of them. This is a new class of device to which we assign the name of, “Varistor-Transistor Hybrid Devices.”

Varistors are simple two terminal ceramic based devices widely used in electrical and electronic circuits to protect them from abrupt surges caused for example by lightning or thunderstorms. In contrast transistors are three terminal devices built conventionally on silicon substrates which are produced by costly and sophisticated materials processing techniques. Our hybrid devices are built on ceramic substrates which are relatively easy and cost effective to produce and can be scaled up for mass production at a reasonable cost. The materials used for this research are oxide semiconductors in the family of iron-titanate. In particular they are ilmenite-hematite with 45 atomic percent hematite (IHC 45) and pseudobrookite (PsB) with a chemical formula of Fe2TiO5.

The output currents of varistors based on IHC45 and PsB have been modified (or tuned) using three external agents, namely, (a) a bias voltage, (b) an electric field provided by a gate oxide, and (c) a magnetic field. After extracting the contributions made by each of these agents on the output signals we obtain the current-voltage characteristics typically found for conventional transistors. They have all the attributes of a transistor and thus can be integrated in integrated circuits to perform the same functions as are achieved presently by conventional silicon based transistors provided speed is not an issue such as in a computer memory. They are well suited for applications in microelectronics, high temperature electronics, and space electronics and possibly in biomedical electronics. These hybrid devices can be alternatively used in the same integrated circuit either as a varistor to protect the circuit or as a transistor to amplify the output signal. This is a definite advantage in favor of these hybrid devices for adopting them in electronic technology.
